bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 4, 1941

div1.p: Hench thanks Kean for writing the Kissingers.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 4, 1941
div1.opener:
Aug 4/41
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
August 4, 1941
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
How very kind and thoughtful you were to write so nicely to
Mrs. Kissinger. When I didn't hear from Kissinger's physician, I wrote
him again, telling him that I assumed my first letter had not been re-
ceived, but again I have not heard from him. Maybe he is one of those
busy country doctors who never answer letters.

At any rate, your kind offices have taken care of matters nicely
and it is now up to Mrs. Kissinger to decide.

I had a letter from Mr. Kellogg of the Wyeth people just last
week, saying that Kissinger was very low and that he was too ill to move.
I certainly hope he doesn't linger long in this pathetic condition. I
have a letter at home half written for you. When in Florida, I got
Bullard's story, with some interesting details. I have written up a
preliminary copy and am sending it to him for correction and amendation.
I am sending you a copy also in a day or two.

My Cleveland talk will be published in Hygeia by Fishbein who
seemed very glad to get it. It is to be illustrated with a colored in-
sert of the painting. I am really very glad that you are one of the
figures in the painting. You certainly deserve that honor.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, Philip S Hench. P. S. Hench, M. D.
So sorry you have been
indisposed again & I do
hope you are feeling better
General J. R. Kean
2804 “N” St. N. W.
Washington, D. C.
